componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that completes the analyst question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'll now return you to The Boeing Company for introductory remarks by Mr.  Tom Downey, Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications. Mr. Downey, please go ahead.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. We will continue with the questions for Jim and Greg. If you have any questions following this part of the session, please call our Media Relations team at (312) 544-2002. Operator, we're ready for the first question. [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: Thank you. We will continue with the questions for Jim and Greg. If you have any questions following this part of the session, please call our Media Relations team at (312) 544-2002. Operator, we're ready for the first question. [Operator Instructions]

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll first go to Jon Ostrower with The Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: And we'll first go to Jon Ostrower with The Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a bit of clarity on the math that you guys presented on the 787 deferred production. Obviously, you're passing $26 billion on deferred costs with 1,100 airplanes to go in your accounting block. And say you're booking a positive margin on each 787, ju
componenttext: Just a bit of clarity on the math that you guys presented on the 787 deferred production. Obviously, you're passing $26 billion on deferred costs with 1,100 airplanes to go in your accounting block. And say you're booking a positive margin on each 787, just really flat out, I mean, to 0 out those deferred costs, just really simple back of the envelope, you need to be generating $25 million in profit per plane starting today. And obviously, there's a curve in there, and you guys haven't hit the unit breakeven yet. So the $25 million figure is even higher than that. So I mean, at what point are the assumptions that you're putting into your accounting estimates and that are generating your record earnings, ultimately, do they reflect the reality of the 787's program cost reductions while ultimately keeping the program stable?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess I would start with, as I said, the fundamental milestones around the 787 being cash-positive and the deferred planning after we reach 12 a month for 2016 haven't changed. And the focus on the program hasn't changed. It's all around, again, b
componenttext: Well, I guess I would start with, as I said, the fundamental milestones around the 787 being cash-positive and the deferred planning after we reach 12 a month for 2016 haven't changed. And the focus on the program hasn't changed. It's all around, again, being more efficient on each unit and capturing additional unit cost. There's initiatives within the supply chain. Obviously, there's initiatives within our factory. And then we're working to capture those and continue the journey on the successful productivity we've had in the program to date. That's what everybody is focused on, ultimately, leading to, again, cash-positive in 2015.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg News.
componenttext: Our next question is from Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg News.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on something that we saw late in 2014. Zodiac had some issues with seat deliveries and certification, and I know it affected some 787 deliveries. And they had -- had cautioned that it's taking longer than they had anticipated to
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on something that we saw late in 2014. Zodiac had some issues with seat deliveries and certification, and I know it affected some 787 deliveries. And they had -- had cautioned that it's taking longer than they had anticipated to straighten some of those issues out. Just wondering if you see any trickle-over into Q1 and if this is a potential -- a warning sign or red flag as you prepare to ramp up 737 and 787 production?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there is no question that seat supply did impact some deliveries and some fall in our production system. We're working through it now. We see it being resolved this year. The -- we regret any impact it has had on our customers, but it's all been w
componenttext: I think there is no question that seat supply did impact some deliveries and some fall in our production system. We're working through it now. We see it being resolved this year. The -- we regret any impact it has had on our customers, but it's all been within our plans and within our guidance as we worked through it. I think the supply base is adjusting to these higher volumes in both 787 and anticipated higher volumes in other programs, and I think they'll be ready.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Doug Cameron with Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Doug Cameron with Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The quarterly Defense question, Jim. You picked up some -- you got funding for some old Growlers in the 2015 budget. What are your thoughts of the timing for the future of the St. Louis line? And does it depend at all on what happens with the Long Range S
componenttext: The quarterly Defense question, Jim. You picked up some -- you got funding for some old Growlers in the 2015 budget. What are your thoughts of the timing for the future of the St. Louis line? And does it depend at all on what happens with the Long Range Strike contest, which is upcoming?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think the status is we're through close to the end of the decade on F-15s, which is a big piece of St. Louis. We've regained momentum on F-18s. I think, in the minds of many, there remains a need beyond that order, so there is a good chance
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think the status is we're through close to the end of the decade on F-15s, which is a big piece of St. Louis. We've regained momentum on F-18s. I think, in the minds of many, there remains a need beyond that order, so there is a good chance that, that line could continue at least to the end of the decade. Although we do not yet have firm orders, that's an assessment. And there is no question that when we win Long Range Strike, and I'm sounding as confident as I can and -- because I do believe we will, that it will solidify the future of St. Louis for many, many years to come.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with The Seattle Times.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with The Seattle Times.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question for Greg. You mentioned delivering some early 787s this year, early-build 787s. There are something like 11 airplanes, usually mostly the "Terrible Teens," as they're called, that have been sitting there for 4 years and more. And about a y
componenttext: Just a question for Greg. You mentioned delivering some early 787s this year, early-build 787s. There are something like 11 airplanes, usually mostly the "Terrible Teens," as they're called, that have been sitting there for 4 years and more. And about a year ago, a couple of customers seemed that those were earmarked for a pullout. Transaero was one of them. So 2 questions about -- or 2 parts of a question about that. First of all, is there any chance those have to be written off or sold so cheaply that it's almost the same thing and we get some accounting charges for those planes? And then secondly, it looks like you want to deliver maybe 3 this year, maybe 3 next year, a very slow output. Is that a deliberate strategy because of the hefty unit cost every time one of them enters the delivery stream?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not at all. The timing of the deliveries is really solely tied to when we finish the work on the aircraft. And frankly, it's a matter of prioritizing the teams, of taking them off the production line and moving them over on the early-build. So that is the
componenttext: Not at all. The timing of the deliveries is really solely tied to when we finish the work on the aircraft. And frankly, it's a matter of prioritizing the teams, of taking them off the production line and moving them over on the early-build. So that is the only thing tied into that. It's really just about finishing up the aircraft for the customers. With regards to the aircraft themselves, we continue to see a viable market, and we're in active discussions with many customers related to those airplanes. So that is fundamentally how we're handling the EMC airplanes. And you're right, I mean, we're working through them in a prudent fashion, and we do expect to deliver 3 or 4 this year.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that will be from Christopher Drew with The New York Times.
componenttext: And that will be from Christopher Drew with The New York Times.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, you mentioned space, and I was just wondering if you could talk just a minute about what it's like to compete with SpaceX, with their lower cost and aggressive lobbying and political clout in Washington, in the various ways that you at Boeing and the
componenttext: Jim, you mentioned space, and I was just wondering if you could talk just a minute about what it's like to compete with SpaceX, with their lower cost and aggressive lobbying and political clout in Washington, in the various ways that you at Boeing and the United Launch Alliance compete with them and what you see happening in the long run in some of these areas.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have respect for SpaceX. I think they offer more limited mission types than we do at this stage and -- but their combination of focus on gaining capability at improved cost is going to benefit the market. It will make us a better competitor in some segm
componenttext: I have respect for SpaceX. I think they offer more limited mission types than we do at this stage and -- but their combination of focus on gaining capability at improved cost is going to benefit the market. It will make us a better competitor in some segments where cost is -- has become more important. I suspect that we will retain the lead in those segments where -- often, manned-type missions that go a long way into many places we've never been before, I see the advantage we have there will sustain itself for a long period of time.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: That concludes our earnings call. Again, for members of the media, if you have further questions, please call our Media Relations team at (312) 544-2002. Thank you.
componenttext: That concludes our earnings call. Again, for members of the media, if you have further questions, please call our Media Relations team at (312) 544-2002. Thank you.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to The Boeing Company's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. The management discussion and slide presentation, plus the analyst and media question-and-answer sessions, are being broad
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to The Boeing Company's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. The management discussion and slide presentation, plus the analyst and media question-and-answer sessions, are being broadcast live over the Internet. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'm turning the call over to Mr. Troy Lahr, Vice President of Investor Relations for The Boeing Company. Mr. Lahr, please go ahead.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Boeing's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Troy Lahr, and with me today are Jim McNerney, Boeing's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, Boeing's Chief Financial Officer. After comments by Jim an
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Boeing's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I'm Troy Lahr, and with me today are Jim McNerney, Boeing's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, Boeing's Chief Financial Officer. After comments by Jim and Greg, we will take your questions. [Operator Instructions]. As always, we've provided detailed financial information in today's press release, and you can follow this broadcast and slide presentation through our website at boeing.com.
Before we begin, I need to remind you that any projections and goals included in our discussion this morning are likely to involve risks, which is the detailed in our news release and our various SEC filings and in the forward-looking statement disclaimer at the end of this web presentation.
In addition, we refer you to our earnings release and presentation for disclosures and reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that we use when discussing our results and outlook.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim McNerney.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Troy, and good morning, everybody. My comments today will focus on our positive first quarter performance in what we see is a continued, healthy and business environment. After that, Greg will walk you through the details of our financial resul
componenttext:
Thank you, Troy, and good morning, everybody. My comments today will focus on our positive first quarter performance in what we see is a continued, healthy and business environment. After that, Greg will walk you through the details of our financial results and outlook.
Now let's move to Slide 2, please. Building on the strong performance trend we sustained through 2014, Boeing delivered solid first quarter 2015 financial results, including higher revenue, healthy core earning -- healthy core operating margins and double-digit growth in core earnings per share. We also continued to return cash to shareholders in the first quarter by repurchasing $2.5 billion of Boeing stock and increasing our dividend, as promised, by 25%, for a payout of $639 million.
Revenue at Boeing Commercial Airplanes increased 21% to $15.4 billion, and operating margins were 10.5%. We delivered 184 commercial airplanes in the quarter and added 110 net new orders. Key milestones in the quarter included delivery of the first 787-9 built at Boeing South Carolina, the opening of our South Carolina propulsion systems facility and start-up of an automated wing panel assembly on the 737 program in Renton.
Boeing Defense, Space & Security reported revenue in the first quarter of $6.7 billion and generated strong operating margins of 11.1%. Key contract awards included orders for 43 AH-64E Apache helicopters, a multiyear combat logistics support contract and an order from SES for an all-electric, 702SP satellite. In addition, the U.S. Air Force selected the 747-8 as the next presidential aircraft.
[indiscernible] program milestones in the quarter included: launching the first 2 all-electric propulsion satellites, double-stacked, on a single rocket and building -- and breaking ground on the crew access tower, which will support the Commercial Crew program and replicating a best practice for bolstering performance on development programs by establishing a single, unified defense and space development programs organization. Our success with a similar structure put in place at Commercial Airplanes, starting with the development of the 787-9, shows that we can leverage synergies and expertise across different development programs to reduce costs and risks and better ensure performance, as promised to our customers. This new organization will oversee current and future development efforts, including work on the KC-46 Tanker, the 747-8 presidential aircraft, our Commercial Crew spacecraft and Space Launch System rocket, the 502 small satellite and our St. Louis-based, 777X work package. In summary, we delivered another strong quarter of operating performance, achieved significant program milestones, captured orders totaling $15 billion and returned significant cash to shareholders, all of which Greg will cover in more detail in a moment.
With that, let's turn to the business environment on Slide 3. Strong airline profitability, healthy global air traffic trends and our backlog totaling more than 5,700 aircraft all combined to underpin our planned production rate increases over the remainder of the decade. Our long-term outlook also remains positive as we expect airline fleet growth and replacement demand to drive the need for nearly 37,000 commercial aircraft over the next 20 years. As evidenced by the healthy pace of orders during the first quarter, conversations with our airline customers continued to center on new purchases or accelerating delivery slots. All requests are still running well below the historical average. These remained very good times for our industry. As I mentioned on last quarter's call, historically, airplane orders are highly correlated to airline profitability, and lower oil prices have not fundamentally changed our customers view on fleet planning or their commitment to existing delivery schedules. The rapid return on investment from new, more efficient airplanes, remains a compelling factor in purchase decisions in a fuel price environment that remains -- even if it remains well below the 15-year average.
As a reminder, in addition to far better fuel efficiency and lower maintenance costs, our new technologically advanced airplanes also often deliver higher passenger and cargo revenue, increased residual values, a better overall passenger experience and greater range that grows market opportunities by allowing for new city pairs and more optimal routes. All of these elements provide significant value to our customers over the life of the aircraft.
Further to those points, demand for both the 777 and 777X remains strong. The 777 production line is essentially sold out for 2016, approximately half sold out in 2017 and has a healthy number of slots already sold firm in 2018. As we've discussed before, the new 777X is scheduled to enter final assembly in the 2018 time frame and will leverage new manufacturing processes and technologies being proven on the current 777 to optimize the overall 777X production system. We will continue to assess the most efficient way to phase in this new technology and adapt, as necessary, to ensure we meet our customers' commitments.
On the 787 program. We have now delivered more than 250 airplanes including 20 -9. Notable among the strong new bookings during the quarter was ANA's orders for 3 787-10s. 787-10 remains on track for first delivery in 2018.
In the single-aisle segment, demand for our new fuel-efficient 737 MAX also remains high, with cumulative orders totaling more than 2,700 airplanes from 57 customers. Development of the MAX remains on track for first delivery in 2017.
Turning to Defense, Space & Security. We continue to see solid support for our major programs. The president's fiscal 2016 budget request included increases for core Boeing production programs such as: P-8A Poseidon, Apache and Chinook helicopters. Key development programs such as Tanker, Long Range Strike and Commercial Crew also saw budget increases. International demand for our offerings remains strong, particularly in the Middle East and the Asia Pacific region. During the first quarter, international customers for Defense, Space & Security represented 23% of revenue and 37% of our current backlog.
Our investments in technology and innovation for organic growth continue in areas such as commercial derivatives, space, unmanned systems, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance and the few critical future franchise programs like Long Range Strike and the T-X Trainer, which are priorities for our customers.
The relative strength of our Defense, Space & Security's business stems from a portfolio that is reliable, proven and affordable, supported by our ongoing market-based affordability initiative, which is focused on reducing operating cost by another $1 billion on top of the $5 billion already achieved, which will ensure competitiveness through the ongoing downturn in domestic defense spending.
Overall, our business strategies are aligned to the realities and the opportunities of our markets, and our teams are executing them well to deliver increased top line and bottom line performance, support the needs of our customers and capture new business to sustain our growth and profitability for the decades to come.
Now over to Greg for our financial results and our updated guidance. Greg?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning. Let's turn to Slide 4, and we'll discuss our first quarter results. First quarter revenue increased 8% to $22.1 billion driven by strong commercial airplane deliveries. Core earnings per share for the quarter increased 12% t
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning. Let's turn to Slide 4, and we'll discuss our first quarter results. First quarter revenue increased 8% to $22.1 billion driven by strong commercial airplane deliveries. Core earnings per share for the quarter increased 12% to $1.97, driven on higher commercial airplane volume and continued strong operating performance.
Let's now discuss Commercial Airplanes on Slide 5. For the first quarter, our Commercial Airplanes business increased revenue 21% to $15.4 billion on 184 airplane deliveries and reported operating margins of 10.5%. Strong operating margins in the quarter were primarily driven by higher volume, continued focus on productivity and program mix. Commercial Airplanes captured $9.8 billion in net orders during the first quarter and backlog remains very strong at $435 billion and over 5,700 aircraft, equating to approximately 8 years of production.
Specifically on the 787 program, we continue to expect the program to be cash positive during 2015, and we still anticipate deferred production to decline shortly after we achieve the 12-per-month production rate in 2016. No change to these fundamental milestones. We continue to see progress in key operational performance indicators for the 787 program as we further implement production efficiencies while meaningfully increasing the 787-9 production and managing through some near-term disruption in supply chain, largely in cabin interiors. Despite these challenges and with a lot of hard work from the team, we delivered 30 787s in the quarter and made further progress on reducing unit cost.
On the 787-8, we've seen a decline in unit cost of approximately 30% over the last 190 deliveries. And furthermore, the 787-9 unit cost declined approximately 25% over the first 20 deliveries. In line with our expectations and as declining rates, 787 deferred production increased $793 million to $27 billion in the first quarter. And as we've previously discussed, we continued to anticipate 787 deferred production to grow at similar levels for the next couple of quarters before seeing a healthy decline in the growth later in this year.
We remain focused on the solid day-to-day execution, risk reduction in improving the long-term productivity and cash flow going forward. We continue to manage the smooth ramp of the 787-9 production, prepare for the 12 rate per month introduction of -10, while also driving efficiencies across all aspects of the program.
Let's turn now to Defense, Space & Security results on Slide 6. First quarter revenue in our defense business was $6.7 billion, and operating margins were strong at 11.1%, largely driven by solid performance and favorable mix. Boeing Military Aircraft first quarter revenue declined to $2.7 billion, primarily driven by planned timing of C-17 and F-15 deliveries. Operating margins of 9.5% reflect delivery mix that offset improved operating performance.
Network & Space Systems reported revenue of $1.7 billion and increased operating margins to 9.6% in the quarter, resulting from higher ULA earnings.
Global Services & Support revenue was $2.2 billion and operating margins increased to 14.1% on solid operating performance and favorable program mix.
Defense, Space & Security reported a solid backlog of $60 billion with 37% of our current backlog representing customers outside the United States.
Next slide, please. Operating cash flow. Operating cash flow for the first quarter was approximately $100 billion, driven by solid operating performance, and as expected, the timing of receipts and expenditures that were largely benefited late in Q4 of 2014. We continue to expect 2015 operating cash flow to be more than $9 billion with the majority of that being generated in the second half of the year.
With regards to capital deployment, as Jim mentioned, we paid $639 million in dividends and repurchased 17 million shares for $2.5 billion in the first quarter as we continue to deliver on our commitment to our shareholders. And furthermore, this reflects our ongoing confidence in the long-term outlook for our business. We continue to anticipate completing the remaining $9.5 billion repurchase authorization over the next 2 to 3 years. Returning cash to shareholders, along with continued investment to support future growth, remains a top priority for us.
Moving to cash and debt balances on Slide 8. We ended the quarter with $9.6 billion of cash and marketable securities, and our cash balance continues to provide solid liquidity and positions us very well going forward.
Let's now turn to Slide 9, and I'll discuss our outlook for 2015. We are reaffirming our 2015 guidance for revenue, operating margins, core earnings, deliveries and cash flow. And overall, we're very pleased with the first quarter performance as the core operating engine continues to deliver strong results, and we expect that performance to continue as we remain focused on production, program profitability, rate ramp-up and ongoing productivity improvements.
With that, I'll turn it back over to Jim for some closing comments.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. With a strong first quarter behind us, we remain focused on disciplined execution, quality and productivity improvements and meeting customer commitments. Our priorities going forward are clear and consistent. The profitable ramp-up in co
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg. With a strong first quarter behind us, we remain focused on disciplined execution, quality and productivity improvements and meeting customer commitments. Our priorities going forward are clear and consistent. The profitable ramp-up in commercial airplane production, executing well on our development programs, driving efficiencies throughout the enterprise, continuing to strengthen our defense business, and importantly, providing increasing value to both our customers and our shareholders.
Now we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about -- there's going to be a number of questions to ask, but you talked about being able to make some real progress with the 777 bridge. Could you elaborate a little bit on that? And Jim, maybe talk about the quality and the characterization
componenttext: You talked about -- there's going to be a number of questions to ask, but you talked about being able to make some real progress with the 777 bridge. Could you elaborate a little bit on that? And Jim, maybe talk about the quality and the characterization of the discussions you're having with customers.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think 777, you've heard my speech before, Howard. Unique airplane in terms of its capability and where it's positioned in the market. So a real opportunity to manage this bridge well. So far, so good. I think last year's performance was good. I thi
componenttext: Yes, I think 777, you've heard my speech before, Howard. Unique airplane in terms of its capability and where it's positioned in the market. So a real opportunity to manage this bridge well. So far, so good. I think last year's performance was good. I think this year, where we stand now, we've got 25 orders and commitments in hand today. That's roughly half or just short of half of what we're looking for for the entire year. I mentioned the production skyline in '16, '17 and '18, and it's beginning to firm up. So we are increasingly confident that we can implement this bridge. And it's important not only commercially and to keep the rate going, but as I mentioned in my comments, we're sort of feathering in some new technology on the current airplane, the ER, so it's tested and de-risked by the time we get to the X. So this bridge has lots of value for us, lots of value for our customers. So steady as she goes.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up for a second. You talked about feathering in some of this technology. And in the press release, you talked about accelerating some of the development milestones. So are we to take that, that, in fact, the R&D programs are -- whether
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up for a second. You talked about feathering in some of this technology. And in the press release, you talked about accelerating some of the development milestones. So are we to take that, that, in fact, the R&D programs are -- whether it's the MAX or the -10 or the X are kind of coming in a little bit better than your current budgets?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, what I would say is, on budget, slightly ahead on de-risking. In other words, things are -- we're spending about what we had planned, but the technical advances or the reliability that we're shooting for is coming in a little bit more robustly than we
componenttext: No, what I would say is, on budget, slightly ahead on de-risking. In other words, things are -- we're spending about what we had planned, but the technical advances or the reliability that we're shooting for is coming in a little bit more robustly than we'd hoped. And as you recall, we've got a development organization that is 100% focused on development now. And that gives us much greater visibility and much more objectivity around these kinds of milestones.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen & Company.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So your 787 deferred per unit build look like they went from 32 in the fourth to 26 million. Maybe give us some color. This looks like better performance than we'd expected. Was this better than your performance expectations? How did the -9 and -8 do? And
componenttext: So your 787 deferred per unit build look like they went from 32 in the fourth to 26 million. Maybe give us some color. This looks like better performance than we'd expected. Was this better than your performance expectations? How did the -9 and -8 do? And is the -8 now in a cash positive mode with regard to deferred?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, but I would say, Cai, when you look over that time frame, we have seen improved performance, and in particular, I noted on the -9 is they're coming down the learning curve at a very aggressive manner. And I think that goes to the lessons learned off
componenttext: Yes, but I would say, Cai, when you look over that time frame, we have seen improved performance, and in particular, I noted on the -9 is they're coming down the learning curve at a very aggressive manner. And I think that goes to the lessons learned off the -8 and getting those into the production system. So that introduction of that airplane is going very well. And as you know, that will be close to half of our deliveries this year. So that smooth introduction is important. When you look quarter-over-quarter, as you know, Cai, mix comes into play. So we did have some early -9s -- actually, the first 2 coming out of Charleston, so that played into the shift quarter-over-quarter. But I say, fundamentally, the program continues to make good improvements on unit costs. Still got a long way to go, but making good progress.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe a follow-up, you've mentioned the cabin interior disruptions. What impact did that have on 8 7? And when do you think you have that behind you?
componenttext: And maybe a follow-up, you've mentioned the cabin interior disruptions. What impact did that have on 8 7? And when do you think you have that behind you?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, Cai, we delivered 30 airplanes, which was the production rate, but it's disruptive. It added additional pressure obviously on deferred. And you see by the growth in deferred, we were able to offset some of that through our own productivity.
componenttext: Well, I mean, Cai, we delivered 30 airplanes, which was the production rate, but it's disruptive. It added additional pressure obviously on deferred. And you see by the growth in deferred, we were able to offset some of that through our own productivity. But certainly, it's been disruptive. There's recovery plans in place. We're part of that recovery. We're actively engaged with them, and we don't see that impacting our delivery through the balance of the year.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next, we go to Doug Hartnett with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And next, we go to Doug Hartnett with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to just continue on that with the 787. If you look at increases that you're seeing in deferred, and as I look at the numbers for this quarter, it looks pretty much on the trajectory you described last quarter. But it -- but can you parse this out
componenttext: I'd like to just continue on that with the 787. If you look at increases that you're seeing in deferred, and as I look at the numbers for this quarter, it looks pretty much on the trajectory you described last quarter. But it -- but can you parse this out into buckets? And what I mean by that is, things that could be onetime investments, I would say, higher costs on early 787-9 deliveries and potentially other factors related to operations of the supply chain. How would you divide this -- I mean, how much falls into each category?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, roughly, Doug, it's about 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 through breaking each one of those pieces out. Certainly, as we talked about maintaining some higher employment as we work through incorporating reliability in driving productivity initiatives, obviously ge
componenttext: I think, roughly, Doug, it's about 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 through breaking each one of those pieces out. Certainly, as we talked about maintaining some higher employment as we work through incorporating reliability in driving productivity initiatives, obviously getting ready to de-risk for the -10 the 12th month and the early introduction of -9. And as you know, you've been covering this business a long time, and this is about a smooth production you've seen on a widebody program, and particularly one that is at record production rates. And that's attributed to really risk-reduction effort and focus early on in the program, some of the supplier negotiations that we talked about moving some of those to the right as we get more mature on the learning curve within those suppliers and then some of the productivity initiatives, as I've highlighted, where we are really seeing opportunities to drive further value in the program over the long term, but requires some upfront investment. Those are very good business cases. Those are absolutely the right things to do to drive long-term profitability and cash of this program. And those obviously remain a top priority for us. And at the same time, we're looking for more opportunities to capture further productivity and cash that will require more investment. So we're continuing to focus on that. And again, I think it's absolutely the right thing to do for the program, and again, driving long-term profitability, and that's the focus.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if I can, I want to follow up on this, I mean, on the -9, I mean on principal, this is an airplane that will have -- has higher pricing. You've done design -- a lot of design work to lower manufacturing costs for it. So in theory, this should be a ver
componenttext: And if I can, I want to follow up on this, I mean, on the -9, I mean on principal, this is an airplane that will have -- has higher pricing. You've done design -- a lot of design work to lower manufacturing costs for it. So in theory, this should be a very attractive airplane from a profitability standpoint. Could you give us a sense of when you expect the -9 to become cash positive?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't really look at it that way, Doug. I mean, I look at it as a program as a whole. And the productivity focus is not just on the -9. It's across the entire value chain of -8 and -9. But again, on the overall profile, when you combine -8 and 9s, we ex
componenttext: I don't really look at it that way, Doug. I mean, I look at it as a program as a whole. And the productivity focus is not just on the -9. It's across the entire value chain of -8 and -9. But again, on the overall profile, when you combine -8 and 9s, we expect to be cash positive during 2015. So that hasn't changed. But the fundamentals are again more across the entire either supply chain or internally, whether it's a -8, a -9 or -10, where do we drive additional productivity.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, I wondered if you might clarify something on the 777 for me. I'm just sort of wondering what the implications of inserting some of these productivity investments into the ER production line or on the margin front for that program? Is that -- by incl
componenttext: Greg, I wondered if you might clarify something on the 777 for me. I'm just sort of wondering what the implications of inserting some of these productivity investments into the ER production line or on the margin front for that program? Is that -- by including those in, and the sort of the end of line of ERs ahead of the 777X, does that have a negative margin impact of any significance? And then secondly, how should we think about the impact of splitting the 777X into its own block and what that will mean for overhead and nonrecurring investments? Is that a material upper in the other direction? How should we think about those impacts?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the first answer -- the answer to your last question is no. As far as introduction of this, we extend the block by 50 [ph] units this quarter, and that investment that we talked about that's going to apply on the 777 and eventually the 777X, I mean,
componenttext: Yes, the first answer -- the answer to your last question is no. As far as introduction of this, we extend the block by 50 [ph] units this quarter, and that investment that we talked about that's going to apply on the 777 and eventually the 777X, I mean, that cost is incorporated. So those are in our booking rates this quarter. I would tell you, a very smooth introduction. When I say that, proving out this technology outside the production system in an isolated -- again, outside the mainstream production, proving it out, making it rate capable and then a smooth implementation as you're continuing to build 8.3 a month. So a lot of that prove out again risk reduction investment up front, but long-term profitability in the program doing that outside of production system. So we've been doing that and that's the, I'll say, the plan to implement that into the mainstream production. So I don't view that as high risk. I think that de-risking activity has been very prudent. And if we see any issues along the way, we have a plan B or, I'd say, an offramp, to continue with the current production system. So I think the risk is very managed. Now the opportunity obviously is in increasing or reducing float time, better quality, and ultimately, better unit cost. So at -- very good investment for us over the long term of the 777 plus the 777X.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And was there any impact on the program margin as a result of the block expansion?
componenttext: And was there any impact on the program margin as a result of the block expansion?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Up or down?
componenttext: Up or down?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Slightly down. And keep in mind, too, Carter, escalation comes into play here that some of the productivity that came through in the booking rates, some of that was offset by escalation that impacted the booking rates across all the programs. But again, s
componenttext: Slightly down. And keep in mind, too, Carter, escalation comes into play here that some of the productivity that came through in the booking rates, some of that was offset by escalation that impacted the booking rates across all the programs. But again, strong productivity across all the programs.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next, we have Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the supply chain and the $2 billion increase in the gross inventory. We know about the seat issue. GE talked about not being able to deliver all the engines that they would've liked. And so I guess,
componenttext: Just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the supply chain and the $2 billion increase in the gross inventory. We know about the seat issue. GE talked about not being able to deliver all the engines that they would've liked. And so I guess, to what extent did those delays impact that inventory number? And where do you see issues in the supply chain that concern you as you talk about going up to 12 a month?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, some of that, Sam, is just effect we're going up in rate. So there's some of that. The disruption, we've talked about, again the team has done a fantastic job managing through the disruption, reaching back into the supply chain and helping w
componenttext: Well, I mean, some of that, Sam, is just effect we're going up in rate. So there's some of that. The disruption, we've talked about, again the team has done a fantastic job managing through the disruption, reaching back into the supply chain and helping wherever we can help out. And there's recovery plans in place. So watch item, certainly been disruptive, but certainly not something we see impacting the deliveries for the year.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you tell us when in 2016 you plan to go to 12 a month?
componenttext: And can you tell us when in 2016 you plan to go to 12 a month?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Later in '16.
componenttext: Later in '16.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: Next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, I was wondering if you might spend a few minutes talking about the defense business. In particular, comment on the sales efforts on the C-17. And then maybe just provide some updated thoughts on, say, the next 5 years in the defense business. Histori
componenttext: Jim, I was wondering if you might spend a few minutes talking about the defense business. In particular, comment on the sales efforts on the C-17. And then maybe just provide some updated thoughts on, say, the next 5 years in the defense business. Historically, you talked about this being flattish with some programs coming up and some coming down. Just an update there would be helpful.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the summary would be the outlook remains challenging, but recently looking a little better, as I read the political dynamics, just overall comment about the marketplace, particularly U.S. Congress-driven marketplace. The -- back to the specifics o
componenttext: I think the summary would be the outlook remains challenging, but recently looking a little better, as I read the political dynamics, just overall comment about the marketplace, particularly U.S. Congress-driven marketplace. The -- back to the specifics of your question, C-17s, we've got orders and commitments that leave about 5 to go. We have a lot of action on those 5s, but I think the team made the right call when to curtail the program. You always want to curtail these things where you end up having a little bit more demand than you've got airplanes at the end. So it's hold pricing and production, and that is playing out well for us. I think the -- in the face of sequestration, the reason for my optimism, and it's not wide-eyed optimism, it's a matter of sort of Ryan-Murray 2.0 sort of maybe extending the kind of budget compromise that have been fashioned a couple of years ago, another couple of years, and that may turn into a broader consensus deal with sequestration in a balanced way. So a little more optimism that that will sort out. And based on newspaper reports I've seen, Murray and Ryan are working together again, trying to come up with some kind of a budget compromise that would include the defense portion. We're well marked up in the president's budget request, more than our fair share of sort of the jump balls, I guess, is the way to put it. And so our backlog remains strong, our profitability, because our productivity plans assumed the worst, and what we'd like to do is be surprised. And so that's the reason you're seeing strong margins in the first quarter in our defense business, notwithstanding some timing on the deliveries, which will sort out by year-end. But it's -- that give you the flavor you were looking for?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just -- maybe just to put a little finer tooth on this. You've got to risk on F-18, F-15 towards the end of the decade. You've all long talked about Tanker and P-8 offsetting those declines. Is that still the broad brush stroke of your view of the wo
componenttext: Yes, just -- maybe just to put a little finer tooth on this. You've got to risk on F-18, F-15 towards the end of the decade. You've all long talked about Tanker and P-8 offsetting those declines. Is that still the broad brush stroke of your view of the world?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and F-18 and F-15 may have more legs to them yet to be proven than the last time I made that comment. So a little bit more bullish there. But long term, that is the way I look at it. The only other thing I'd add to that is that there are 3 or 4 major
componenttext: Yes, and F-18 and F-15 may have more legs to them yet to be proven than the last time I made that comment. So a little bit more bullish there. But long term, that is the way I look at it. The only other thing I'd add to that is that there are 3 or 4 major development programs that are in play right now. Long Range Strike is one. Tanker is another one. The U classes another one. And so there's still major programs in. If we win our market, or sort of our market shares worth of those or maybe a little better, that will provide some upside to the equation you mentioned.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on customer advances. It seems like more recently that's been more volatile than it has been in the past. And just kind of thinking about it, has there been a change in policy around how you collect the PDP's meeting with backlogs go
componenttext: Just a quick question on customer advances. It seems like more recently that's been more volatile than it has been in the past. And just kind of thinking about it, has there been a change in policy around how you collect the PDP's meeting with backlogs going out so far? Is it to your advantage to try and collect some of those PDPs monetizing it sooner than waiting, say, 8 years for this PDP? Does that make sense?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No change, Ron. No change. I mean, what you're really just seeing is just the timing of those. And as you've heard me talk about before, as you go up in rate, and obviously with a strong order book, we've seen more advances. But the timing of those quarte
componenttext: No change, Ron. No change. I mean, what you're really just seeing is just the timing of those. And as you've heard me talk about before, as you go up in rate, and obviously with a strong order book, we've seen more advances. But the timing of those quarter-over-quarter, very difficult to see a trend there. And you really got to look at it over a year-over-year, and frankly, over a 24-month period because of the size of those, some of those as well as milestone payments. So very difficult to look at it on a quarter-over-quarter base. But no change. I would say as far as cash flow goes, the outlook for operating cash from us remains unchanged, and we still see strong cash flow this year, again greater than $9 billion [ph] and continued growth as we come out of '15 into '16. Advances are certainly a part of that, but just the core operating performance and the fact that our delivery rates will continue to go up as we deliver on the 5,700 airplanes. So our view on cash flow again is very solid and remains unchanged.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I can just follow up on, just a more technical question. On the 777X, it -- I think you guys have said that the center wing box is going to be aluminum as opposed to carbon fiber. How -- what can we read into that -- and with that
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I can just follow up on, just a more technical question. On the 777X, it -- I think you guys have said that the center wing box is going to be aluminum as opposed to carbon fiber. How -- what can we read into that -- and with that move on that aircraft compared to what was done on the 787?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't read anything into it, Ron. Obviously, when we go through the design of the airplane, I won't pretend to be a design engineer here, but everything is taken into consideration as far as the efficiency of the operating economics of the airplane a
componenttext: I wouldn't read anything into it, Ron. Obviously, when we go through the design of the airplane, I won't pretend to be a design engineer here, but everything is taken into consideration as far as the efficiency of the operating economics of the airplane and the weight. And that gets taken into consideration, maturity of technology, and obviously, development cost and recurring cost to build the airplane. So those are a few things are obviously some key factors we take into account when we're making trade-offs between one type of, say, application versus another.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And there was no change there. That was always the plan.
componenttext: And there was no change there. That was always the plan.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, you did 10.5% of BCA margins in the quarter. It looks like mix and volume will actually be modest [indiscernible] to the rest of the year. It doesn't look like R&D should be much of a headwind, and it sounds like the 777 [indiscernible] extension wa
componenttext: Greg, you did 10.5% of BCA margins in the quarter. It looks like mix and volume will actually be modest [indiscernible] to the rest of the year. It doesn't look like R&D should be much of a headwind, and it sounds like the 777 [indiscernible] extension was kind of a negative in this quarter. So other than conservatism, how do you put it to the 9% to 10% guidance for the year?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I kind of put it into 3 main areas, Myles. I mean, R&D, we do expect R&D to pick up a little bit in the back half with -- in particular 777X ramping up. We'll have more -9 deliveries, 787-9 deliveries. And then, with the more 747s as well. So that's
componenttext: Yes, I kind of put it into 3 main areas, Myles. I mean, R&D, we do expect R&D to pick up a little bit in the back half with -- in particular 777X ramping up. We'll have more -9 deliveries, 787-9 deliveries. And then, with the more 747s as well. So that's the, say, the diluted impact for the margins going through the balance of the year. And having said that, obviously, we got everybody extremely focused on continuing [indiscernible] and we will through the balance of the year, but it's really that mix that's driving.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one clarification. You said the majority of cash in the second half, are you thinking 2/3? Or are you talking 80%?
componenttext: Just one clarification. You said the majority of cash in the second half, are you thinking 2/3? Or are you talking 80%?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, traditionally, as you know, we're backloaded, but third and fourth quarter will be heavier than the first and second quarter. And again, progress payments, milestones and then just delivery profile.
componenttext: Well, I would say, traditionally, as you know, we're backloaded, but third and fourth quarter will be heavier than the first and second quarter. And again, progress payments, milestones and then just delivery profile.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Rob Spingarn with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Rob Spingarn with Crdit Suisse.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get a clarification from Jim and then a question for Greg. Jim, on the 777, you've mentioned 25 orders and commitments, but I think you printed just the 7 orders in the quarter. So are these still in process? Or are they falling into Q
componenttext: So I just wanted to get a clarification from Jim and then a question for Greg. Jim, on the 777, you've mentioned 25 orders and commitments, but I think you printed just the 7 orders in the quarter. So are these still in process? Or are they falling into Q2?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't mention commitments unless things are largely done. And so things are largely done, and there's timing considerations, and in some cases, driven by customer requirements and things and so. So we let the customer decide when to finally fund
componenttext: Well, we don't mention commitments unless things are largely done. And so things are largely done, and there's timing considerations, and in some cases, driven by customer requirements and things and so. So we let the customer decide when to finally fund the approve and release. But I have a very high degree of confidence in that 25 number.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And Greg, on the capital, just going back, just a follow-up to Ron's question. So you probably have, let's call it, after tax, a $1 billion to $2 billion tailwind on 787 deferred, and you're guiding to a flattish OC, operating cash flow, somew
componenttext: Okay, okay. And Greg, on the capital, just going back, just a follow-up to Ron's question. So you probably have, let's call it, after tax, a $1 billion to $2 billion tailwind on 787 deferred, and you're guiding to a flattish OC, operating cash flow, somewhat flattish net income and I know timings work there a little bit. But given that, how should we think about the advance and physical inventory balances at the end of the year here? I imagine that there's some offset to the 7 -- to the deferred tailwind in terms of a headwind on advances and physical inventory?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, like I said, Rob, timing around advances and milestones can swing significantly quarter-over-quarter, and you he said, year-over-year. So that comes into play as long as -- as well as, as I said, delivery mix and even the way the orders are pro
componenttext: Yes, well, like I said, Rob, timing around advances and milestones can swing significantly quarter-over-quarter, and you he said, year-over-year. So that comes into play as long as -- as well as, as I said, delivery mix and even the way the orders are profiled through the balance of the y r. So again, the outlook on cash flow for this year, unchanged. Greater than $9 billion, that's what everybody's focused on Generating again quarter-over-quarter, you're going to see variance in there. And those at -- those elements I described are really what the big chips in quarter-over-quarter, I'll say, fluctuation you're going to see. But nothing's change on the cash flow, Rob, and we continue to remain extremely focused. And I think as you've seen $2.5 billion share repurchase in the quarter alone, I think should give you some idea of the confidence we have in executing to our business plan and just the overall business environment and executing on the total backlog.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: But Greg, just to be clear, you can do the $9 billion [ph] even if the advance balances declined?
componenttext: But Greg, just to be clear, you can do the $9 billion [ph] even if the advance balances declined?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't anticipate any change from what we've talked about when we gave guidance. So again, I see advances about flattish year-over-year from 2014, but those are all scheduled. We know where they're timed, and we know where they're coming from, and
componenttext: Well, we don't anticipate any change from what we've talked about when we gave guidance. So again, I see advances about flattish year-over-year from 2014, but those are all scheduled. We know where they're timed, and we know where they're coming from, and we have confidence that we'll obtain all of those as we normally do. So I don't see any change there.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: And our next question is from Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jim, question on the -- you mentioned the deferral request continuing to run at record low, record kind of accelerated purchases. Do you still feel confident about kind of the bookings environment? I guess, it speaks of the health of your backlog. But do
componenttext: Jim, question on the -- you mentioned the deferral request continuing to run at record low, record kind of accelerated purchases. Do you still feel confident about kind of the bookings environment? I guess, it speaks of the health of your backlog. But do you still think you can get a book-to-bill of 1 for this year?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we'll get a book-to-bill of 1. I mean, there's -- When I look at a pipeline, I look at what's happened so far in the first quarter, that remains, how I see it, coming in. And I think that's a healthy sign after a number of years that well abo
componenttext: Yes, I think we'll get a book-to-bill of 1. I mean, there's -- When I look at a pipeline, I look at what's happened so far in the first quarter, that remains, how I see it, coming in. And I think that's a healthy sign after a number of years that well above that. But it's remember a lot of the demand out there is replacement demand, new technology replacing old technology. We're in a technology cycle now. We're not tied to GDP growth. We are tied to a very favorable replacement economics. And so half our growth is replacement, half is sort of new routes, no airlines opening up, new deliveries more tied to GDP. But that's the nice thing about what innovation can do for you.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And is there any concerns about -- just when you mentioned oil, you're not seeing any pushback just related to that, are you? Some of your leasing customers, I mean, has production rates not to go up as where they -- as high as they indicated? Are you wor
componenttext: And is there any concerns about -- just when you mentioned oil, you're not seeing any pushback just related to that, are you? Some of your leasing customers, I mean, has production rates not to go up as where they -- as high as they indicated? Are you worried about kind of the capacity aspect? Or is it just related to that replacement cycle?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- said another way, the replacement cycle numbers still worked really well with oil at current prices. Remember, we launched the 787 at roughly 20%, 25% lower oil prices than we have today, okay? So we felt very confident then and we even mo
componenttext: Yes, I think -- said another way, the replacement cycle numbers still worked really well with oil at current prices. Remember, we launched the 787 at roughly 20%, 25% lower oil prices than we have today, okay? So we felt very confident then and we even more so do now in a higher oil price environment from them that this is an attractive proposition for a customer. And as I said, the order trends relate more, when you just look at the stats, you look at the [indiscernible] they relate more to airline profitability that it does to temporary fluctuations in the dollar or oil prices. And going up, we're very profitable now.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that will be from the line of Hunter Key with Wolfe research.
componenttext: And that will be from the line of Hunter Key with Wolfe research.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sort of a follow-up the previous question actually, it was about the historical -- the comments you made in the last calls about running below historical deferral cancellation rates. I mean, can you give us some more color? How are you tracking that? Do y
componenttext: Sort of a follow-up the previous question actually, it was about the historical -- the comments you made in the last calls about running below historical deferral cancellation rates. I mean, can you give us some more color? How are you tracking that? Do you look back at that metric to sort of where we are in prior cycles at this point in time? Or is it just like a rolling, historical lookback? Is there anyway you can give us a more color on how you look at that metric and help us sort of think about it and quantifying it?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's sort of a rolling look back at sort of a rolling metric. I think this question, I sort of started working this into representations when we -- and this is before the last -- back in the last dip and people were concerned, rightly so, about that
componenttext: Yes, it's sort of a rolling look back at sort of a rolling metric. I think this question, I sort of started working this into representations when we -- and this is before the last -- back in the last dip and people were concerned, rightly so, about that metric. And we've just sort of kept it in place, and -- but just in my experience over the last decade, we have remained at the bottom-ish parts of the cycle, top part of the cycle, the last decade or so, we've remained below that historical average, which is a good thing. We can break up the number for your little more finely, if you'd like. But general, I think the point is valid through the cycles over the last 10 years.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great and Greg, maybe a quick follow-up for you other comments you made about advance [indiscernible] being roughly flat. I thought you said at a conference last month that there were going to be down a little bit because of a lack of rate breaks. O
componenttext: Okay, great and Greg, maybe a quick follow-up for you other comments you made about advance [indiscernible] being roughly flat. I thought you said at a conference last month that there were going to be down a little bit because of a lack of rate breaks. Or just try to be to these PDPs advances line that would cause that disconnect? Or maybe just -- did I miss area?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I was talking noncommercial. There's a little bit more on the BDS side driving that.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I was talking noncommercial. There's a little bit more on the BDS side driving that.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: That completes the analysts question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn you to the Boeing Company for introductory remarks of Mr. Tom Downey, Senior Vice President, Communications. Mr. Downey, please go ahead.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext:
Thank you. We'll continue this morning with media questions for Jim and Greg. If you have any questions following this part of this session, please call our Media Relations team at (312) 544-2002.
Operator, we're ready for the first question. [Operator Instructions]

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Don [indiscernible] with Wall Street Journal.
componenttext: And we'll go to Don [indiscernible] with Wall Street Journal.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Question about Boeing South Carolina. The IAM withdrew their request for election there late last week. I'm just curious, Jim, your thoughts on the site today. And looking forward, as far as the relations with the Union, more broadly, or whether or not th
componenttext: Question about Boeing South Carolina. The IAM withdrew their request for election there late last week. I'm just curious, Jim, your thoughts on the site today. And looking forward, as far as the relations with the Union, more broadly, or whether or not there are any lessons to learn from how Boeing has dealt with its workforce there in terms of more broadly looking at what's going on back in Puget Sound and sort of how to manage that relationship and whether or not they're essentially Boeing South Carolina, your view -- do you have to stay non-union to be a competitive site?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Listen, I mean, you're right. I mean they decided not to go through the election presumably -- because they felt they didn't have the votes, but you have to ask them specifically about why they withdrew. We are very happy with our relationship with our te
componenttext: Listen, I mean, you're right. I mean they decided not to go through the election presumably -- because they felt they didn't have the votes, but you have to ask them specifically about why they withdrew. We are very happy with our relationship with our teammates down in South Carolina. The site is technically and on a manufacturing certification, engineering basis, doing very well. I'm very pleased with its progress. Is the -- but I also highly value the relationship that I -- that we all have with our employees in Puget Sound. I mean, it's -- we -- one group has a union, one doesn't. We prefer to have a direct relationship with our employees, but when they choose to have a union, we want to work with them. So it's not either/or. Our task is to work with both environments and to grow them to their potential. And so -- but very happy with developments down in South Carolina. That place is really doing very well.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg News.
componenttext: Our next question is from Julie Johnsson with Bloomberg News.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Airbus said today that they're looking at boosting A320 production past 16 [ph] months. And I'm just wondering if Boeing is studying a similar increase in narrowbody output. And if there are concerns at this point about the supply chain's ability to keep
componenttext: Airbus said today that they're looking at boosting A320 production past 16 [ph] months. And I'm just wondering if Boeing is studying a similar increase in narrowbody output. And if there are concerns at this point about the supply chain's ability to keep pace with some of the increases coming down.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I didn't see Airbus's comments today. But I think our supply chain has anticipated robust growth, probably from both of us. They see the orders and the backlogs as we do. We spend a lot of time talking with our supply chain, working on them with readiness
componenttext: I didn't see Airbus's comments today. But I think our supply chain has anticipated robust growth, probably from both of us. They see the orders and the backlogs as we do. We spend a lot of time talking with our supply chain, working on them with readiness, on readiness issues, I should say. We've announced 52. They count a little bit differently. 60 is not roughly the same as 52, 54. I've forgotten how the math works, but it's -- I think the supply chain is ready, and we spent a lot of time investing in getting them ready.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dominic Gates of the Seattle Times.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dominic Gates of the Seattle Times.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask for an update on Tanker. And very specifically, we learned from the G&A over port this month a couple of things. First of all, the flight tester going to go -- again to start production ahead of the flight test. So can you speak to the ris
componenttext: I wanted to ask for an update on Tanker. And very specifically, we learned from the G&A over port this month a couple of things. First of all, the flight tester going to go -- again to start production ahead of the flight test. So can you speak to the risk of that? And a very specific question, the G&A over report says that Boeing's own estimates of the cost overruns on the initial development phase is $380 million. [ph] Is that the amount covered by the charge you took last July, the pretax 4 25 million? Or is that some anticipated new charge later?

componenttext: I'm not sure about the last number.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: There's no anticipated charge there, Dominic.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: I don't know where you've got it from.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our estimates taken all that into consideration and first light as well as completing the balance of the airplanes. Certainly, there is work left to be done here in Redmond get the airplane into the air sometime this summer. And that will be fully militar
componenttext: Our estimates taken all that into consideration and first light as well as completing the balance of the airplanes. Certainly, there is work left to be done here in Redmond get the airplane into the air sometime this summer. And that will be fully militarized and we'll see how that goes and continue to execute the balance of the program, but there's no change to the financial position on the program at this point.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that will be from Alan Scott from Reuters.
componenttext: And that will be from Alan Scott from Reuters.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could say a bit more about why you feel confident that the Zodiac C problems are resolved? They said today that got to the root of the problem, but that they're still anticipating some disruptions. Can you tell me more about that what gi
componenttext: I wondered if you could say a bit more about why you feel confident that the Zodiac C problems are resolved? They said today that got to the root of the problem, but that they're still anticipating some disruptions. Can you tell me more about that what gives you confidence that it won't disrupt their deliveries this year?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think all the problems are not resolved. We do have a high confidence in the plan to resolve them. We have -- that's because our people are deeply involved with them in the resolution, the -- we don't anticipate a lot of it being worked through til
componenttext: Yes, I think all the problems are not resolved. We do have a high confidence in the plan to resolve them. We have -- that's because our people are deeply involved with them in the resolution, the -- we don't anticipate a lot of it being worked through till the end of the second quarter. But it's -- we've all figured out a way to work together that is -- it's not going to disrupt our production plans. And we're pleased to see their response now to getting this fixed.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
