headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone and welcome to the Boeing Company's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.The management discussion and slide presentation plus the analysts and media question-and-answe
componenttext:
Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone and welcome to the Boeing Company's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
The management discussion and slide presentation plus the analysts and media question-and-answer sessions are being broadcast live over the Internet. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'm turning the call over to Mr. Troy Lahr, Investor Relations for the Boeing company. Mr. Lahr, please go ahead.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Boeing's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I am Troy Lahr, and with me today is Dennis Muilenburg, Boeing's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, Boeing's Chief Financial Officer. And after manageme
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Boeing's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. I am Troy Lahr, and with me today is Dennis Muilenburg, Boeing's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, Boeing's Chief Financial Officer. And after management comments, we will take your questions. [Operator Instructions] through our website at boeing.com.
Before we begin, I need to remind you that any projections and goals in our discussion today are likely to involve risk, which is detailed in our news release, various SEC filings and the forward-looking statement disclaimer in the presentation.
In addition, we refer you to our earnings release and presentation for disclosures and reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that we use when discussing our results and outlook. Now I'll turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Troy, and good morning. I'll start with some comments on the quarter and our business environment, after that, Greg will walk through details for financial results and outlook. With that lets move to Slide 2. Boeing delivered strong third qua
componenttext:
Thank you, Troy, and good morning. I'll start with some comments on the quarter and our business environment, after that, Greg will walk through details for financial results and outlook. 
With that lets move to Slide 2. Boeing delivered strong third quarter operating performance with 9% revenue growth, 10.2% core operating margins, 18% growth in core earnings per share and operating cash flow of $2.9 billion. Given our operating performance in the quarter, we are raising 2015 guidance for revenue, core EPS and operating cash flow. This performance and confidence in our long-term outlook continues to support our commitment to return cash to shareholders while also making strategic investments to grow our business. Year-to-date, we've returned nearly $8 billion to shareholders through share repurchase and dividends. This remains a priority under our balance cash deployment strategy. Revenue at Boeing Commercial airplanes increased 10% on record deliveries of our industry-leading product family. During the quarter, we delivered our 325th 787. We began final assembly and achieved power on for the 737 MAX, completed firm configuration on the 777x and successfully completed final testing and began implementing the advanced automation fuselage technology on the 777 line, which will improve safety, quality and flow time and ensure a smooth transition to the 777x. Boeing Defense Space and Security grew its top line by 6% on higher revenue at Boeing Military aircraft, and network and space systems. Key contract awards during the quarter included in orders from India were 22 Apache attack helicopters and 15 Chinook heavylift helicopters and a contract from Japan for 5  V-22 rotary aircraft. We also received a contract from the U.S. Navy for 13 additional P-8A Poseidon aircraft. Significant defense program milestones included delivery of the first 2 of 12 EA-18 Growlers to the Royal Australian Air Force and the start of flight testing of the first pull off KC-46A aerial refueling tanker. During the last few weeks, we have successfully deployed the tankers refueling boom and its line and refueling systems multiple times over a broad range of flight additions. While more work remains ahead, these early accomplishments represent significant risk reductions and real progress from the flight test program. In summary, we had another strong partner of operating performance and cash generation. 
With that, let's turn to the business environment on Slide 3. The commercial airplane business environment generally remains healthy, driven by improving airline profitability, solid air passenger traffic and meaningful replacement demand. Air cargo traffic remains a watch target for us as a gradual market recovery continues and amid modest overall global economic growth rates. Airplane order activity and customer discussions are continuing at a moderated but historically healthy pace. Deferral requests and cancellations remain well below the historical average. In the single-aisle segment, demand for our new fuel-efficient 737 MAX remains high with cumulative orders totaling nearly 2,900 airplanes from 58 customers. Given the strong market demand, we continue to see upward pressure on narrowbody production rates, beyond the announced 52 per month in 2018. However, we remained steadfast in our financial discipline as we assess the market demand for further production rate changes. 
During the third quarter, we made the decision to increase the 767 production rate to 2.5 per month starting in 2017, driven by ongoing strong demand for the 767 freighter on top of the existing plan tanker production base. This is a testament to the compelling value proposition that airplane brings to the market. Demand also remained strong for the 777x, with the backlog of 306 aircraft from 6 customers. On the 777, we have 44 orders and commitments year-to-date including the 2 777-300 ERs announced last week for EVA Airways. Our 777 backlog stands at 235 aircraft with production for 2016 essentially sold out, and 2017 production more than half sold. With firm configuration of that 777x complete and our manufacturing advanced taking hold, we are now working to finalize the production plan to phase in this new technology. We will also continue to assess 777 supply and demand to maximize airplane profitability over the transition period. On the 787 program EVA's decision last week to also purchase up to 24 787-10 is evidenced of strong continued market demand for the Dreamliner. The 787 backlog of nearly 800 orders fully supports our planned production rate increases to 12 per month for 2016 and 14 per month later this decade. We have now delivered more than 330 787s, including more than 50 Dash 9. 
Turning to defense base and security. We continue to see solid support for major programs. Congress has been supportive of the President's fiscal year 2016 VOD and NASA budget request basis to core Boeing programs, including the P-8A Poseidon, the F-18 Super Hornet, Apache and Chinook helicopters and the NASA's Space Launch System. International demand for our offerings remained strong, particularly in the Middle East and the Asia-Pacific region. 
During the third quarter, international customers for defense space and security represents 35% of revenue and 40% of our current backlog. The strength of our defense and space business stems from our investments in technology and innovation that have established the portfolio of reliable, proven and affordable products and services. We continue to invest in organic growth areas that are priorities for our customers, such as commercial derivatives, space, unmanned systems, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance, and the critical few future franchise programs like long-range strike and the T-X Trainer. Teams throughout our company continue to ensure our long-term competitiveness made driving further safety, quality and productivity gains to improve program profitability and fund investment in future growth. In summary, our team is executing on our business strategy by growing revenues, generating solid operating performance and capturing strategic new business. 
Now over to Greg for our financial results and our updated guidance. Greg?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis, and good morning, everybody. Let's turn to Slide 4, and we'll discuss our third quarter results. Third quarter revenue increased 9% to $25.8 billion, driven by record commercial airplane deliveries. Core operating margins of 10.2% reflects
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis, and good morning, everybody. Let's turn to Slide 4, and we'll discuss our third quarter results. Third quarter revenue increased 9% to $25.8 billion, driven by record commercial airplane deliveries. Core operating margins of 10.2% reflects solid execution across both businesses. Core earnings per share for the quarter increased 18% to $2.52, reflecting, again, continued strong core operating performance on production programs and within our services business. Let's now discuss Commercial Airplanes on Slide 5. For the third quarter, Boeing Commercial Airplanes revenue increased 10% to $17.7 billion on a record 199 airplane deliveries. BCA operating margin of 10% reflects strong execution, offset by the impact of higher planned R&D spending and increased 787 deliveries. Commercial Airplanes captured $13 billion of net orders during the third quarter and backlog remains very strong at $426 billion and nearly 5,700 aircraft equating to more than 7 years of production. Specifically on the 787, we continue to expect the program to be cash positive in the fourth quarter, and we still anticipate the production to declined shortly after we achieve the 12 per month production rate later in 2016. No change to these fundamental milestones. 
We continue to see progress in the key operational performance indicators for the 787 program as we implement additional production efficiency while meaningfully increasing 787-9 production. As planned, the 787-9 production rate and deliveries are now outpacing 787-8. This is a testament to the team's detailed advanced planning and day-to-day execution to ensure a smooth transition and ramp up of the 787-9. 
On the 787-8, we have continued to make progress on unit cost production, where we now see a decline of approximately 40% over the last 230 deliveries. We've also made further progress in the 787-9, where we now have had more than 30% cost reduction over the first 50 deliveries. Driven by continued cost reductions, a healthy mix of Dash 9s and the benefit of favorable timing on quarterly spending 787 deferred production increased $577 million to now a balance of $28.3 billion in the third quarter. We continue to anticipate 787 deferred production growth to further decline in the fourth quarter. We still have work ahead of us in the 787 as we remain focused on the solid day-to-day execution and risk mitigation while improving the long-term productivity and cash flow going forward. We will continue to manage the smooth ramp up of the 787-9 production, prepare for the 12 per month introduction and introduce the Dash 10 while, again, driving efficiencies across all aspects of the program. 
Let's now turn to Slide 6 to discuss Defense, Space & Security results. BDS reported strong results in the quarter with revenue increasing 6% to $8.4 billion, and operating margins of 12.2% on strong performance and a favorable delivery mix. Boeing Military Aircraft third quarter revenue increased 15% to $4.1 billion, largely driven by F-15 contract negotiations. Operating margins were 12.2% in the quarter, reflecting higher volumes and strong performance. Network and space revenue increased 5% to $2.1 billion, driven by commercial crude volume. The segment also generated strong operating margins of 11.5% on favorable mix and productivity improvements. Global services and support revenue declined to $2.2 billion, largely driven by timing of deliveries while operating margins were strong at 12.9%. Defense, Space & Security captured $9 billion of orders during the quarter and reported to solid backlog of $59 billion. 
Let's move to cash flow now on Slide 7. Operating cash flow for the third quarter was strong at $2.9 billion, driven by higher volumes and solid operating performance. And with regards to capital deployment, we paid $618 million in dividend and repurchased 11 million shares for $1.5 billion in the third quarter as we continue to deliver on our commitment of returning cash to shareholders. Year-to-date, we have returned $8 billion to shareholders through dividends and repurchased 41 million shares. Again, this reflects our commitment and confidence in the long-term outlook for our business. Returning cash to shareholders, along with continued investments support future growth remain high priority for us. 
Let's now move to cash and debt balances on Slide 8. We ended the quarter with $9.9 billion of cash and marketable securities. Our cash balance continues to provide solid liquidity and positions us well going forward. Let's now turn to Slide 9 and will discuss our outlook for the balance of 2015. Based on the strong operating performance year-to-date, we've increased our 2015 guidance for revenue, operating margins, core earnings per share and operating cash flow. Core earnings per share guidance for 2015 has increased $0.25 to now be between $7.95 and $8.15 a share on continued solid execution across the business. The company revenue guidance increased $500 million, now be between $95 billion and $97 billion on higher commercial airplane deliveries. BCA delivery guidance has increased now 5 airplanes to be from 755 to 760. Defense, Space & Security operating margins guidance has increased to approximately 10%, again, reflecting strong operating efficiencies across the business. Operating cash flow has increased to approximately $9.5 billion on improved performance across the company as well as favorable timing of receipts and expenditures. And furthermore, we're lowering our R&D guidance, $100 million to now be $3.4 billion for the year to reflect timing of spending. In the fourth quarter, we expect BCA margins to be impacted by the strong operating performance somewhat offset by delivery mix and higher planned R&D spending on 777x as well as additional investments in productivity initiatives.
So in summary, we generated solid revenue growth and healthy operating margins while generating significant cash flow. We meaningfully return cash to shareholders and invested in our future. And with that, I'll turn the call back over to Dennis for closing comments.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. With 3 solid quarters behind us, we remain focused on discipline execution, quality and productivity improvements and meeting customer commitments. Our priorities going forward are clear and consistent. The profitable ramp-up in commercia
componenttext: Thank you, Greg. With 3 solid quarters behind us, we remain focused on discipline execution, quality and productivity improvements and meeting customer commitments. Our priorities going forward are clear and consistent. The profitable ramp-up in commercial airplane production, delivering on our development programs, continuing to strengthen our defense and space business, driving productivity and performance throughout the enterprise to fund our investments in innovation, talent and technology and importantly, providing increasing value to our customers and our shareholders. Now with that, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Harned with Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Harned with Bernstein.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm going to probably violate this a little bit because I wanted to get some clarity on the deferred production ramp as part of this question. So when you look forward, you're talking about being cash positive in Q4 on the 787, and my understanding was th
componenttext: I'm going to probably violate this a little bit because I wanted to get some clarity on the deferred production ramp as part of this question. So when you look forward, you're talking about being cash positive in Q4 on the 787, and my understanding was that would be followed by a plateau in '16 and then that would ramp down as you took rate up toward the back part of '16. I just want to make sure that, that is still the -- still how you're thinking about this.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is how you're thinking about it?
componenttext: That is how you're thinking about it?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Exactly, yes, yes. Doubt, that's exactly right, and that remains consistent, and we're confident in that profile.
componenttext: Exactly, yes, yes. Doubt, that's exactly right, and that remains consistent, and we're confident in that profile.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: But -- okay, great. And then the second part is, when you look out towards the end of the block, when we look at this, the deferred production levels suggest to us that when you get on the later portion of the block, you're going to have to have unit cash
componenttext: But -- okay, great. And then the second part is, when you look out towards the end of the block, when we look at this, the deferred production levels suggest to us that when you get on the later portion of the block, you're going to have to have unit cash margin move to about 25% for the program. Now that's our pretty good number. And what I'd like to know first is, is that correct? And then second, how do you see the path to getting there?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I won't get into the specific program by program margin, but I will give you a sense of kind of I'll say the few areas that are focused on that have been in the past, and that will be the path forward to continue to drive 787 profitability. C
componenttext: Well, again, I won't get into the specific program by program margin, but I will give you a sense of kind of I'll say the few areas that are focused on that have been in the past, and that will be the path forward to continue to drive 787 profitability. Certainly productivity continuing to come down the learning curve internally. You've heard us talk about the progress-to-date on the 787-9 and the 787-8, so that's got to continue. And we got a lot of projects and work. We've got to get those matured, and we got to get them cut in on line numbers. So there's not a lack of, I'll say, focus, and ideas on that areas. But we got to get them matured and get them in, but continuing to execute enough as we have on the productivity. Mix plays a big factor in here. And so our ability with a richer mix of Dash 9s and 10s. And quite frankly, as you see the Dash 9 get entered into the production system as smooth as it is another, I think, indicator of that mix coming together. And keeping in mind, this is all in our backlog. So this is delivering on the backlog, but getting that smooth introduction and having that richer mix of Dash 9s and 10s will obviously grow as you get further out on that cost base and deliver on that backlog. The supply chain, obviously, we've got planned step down and contractual step down, but we've also got initiatives that we're working together across -- in the company and across the supply chain, looking for additional productivity ideas. And keeping in mind, there's only been 300 units built here, roughly. And very steep ramp up and a lot of change in rate break having being stable at 10, and then now making that transition up to 12. This is when you look historically, this is where you been able to capture additional productivity gains. So we're working with the supply-chain on that. And then rate. As you know, we are going up in rate, and it will total about 40% going up to 12 a month in '16, and then 14 a month later in 2019, '20 timeframe. So making good progress in getting up to rate within the supply chain as well as getting the factories ready internally. Again, this is delivering on the backlog and you know the market. And so that support these rate increases very much. But again, that will continue to drive productivity. And then I guess the only comment I'd make on the margins, I'd say, they are similar to what we see today on our widebody programs and what we're achieving. So I'd say good progress to date, a lot of work ahead of us to do teams got good plans in place, but we need to keep executing as we have, and that will be the path going forward.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Doug, just to add a little more color to that. As Greg said, each of those dimensions, we have real and firm actions underway, I could tell you, myself Greg and Ray and the whole team, this is a very important high-priority focus area for us. And in e
componenttext: And Doug, just to add a little more color to that. As Greg said, each of those dimensions, we have real and firm actions underway, I could tell you, myself Greg and Ray and the whole team, this is a very important high-priority focus area for us. And in each of these productivity dimensions that Greg talked about, the advantage we have here goes to that -- to the fact that we've got 800 of these aircraft roughly in backlog. So this gives us the opportunity to do that long-term planning and engagement and to drive profitability with that long-term view. And that is what's going to drive us down the learning curve to get to those objectives that Gregg mentioned.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: But as part of that trajectory,  then presumably, you still have a number of contractual step downs in the supply chain that you're looking forward to and that you know -- that you have a pretty good handle on, I guess?
componenttext: But as part of that trajectory,  then presumably, you still have a number of contractual step downs in the supply chain that you're looking forward to and that you know -- that you have a pretty good handle on, I guess?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: We do, Doug. And that includes the success of brother that we talked about before, that includes committed step downs that are in the plan and a continuing effort to drive value generation. So our value engineering effort that we talked about before with
componenttext: We do, Doug. And that includes the success of brother that we talked about before, that includes committed step downs that are in the plan and a continuing effort to drive value generation. So our value engineering effort that we talked about before with our supply chain network more than 1,000  ideas in the pipeline right now that we're moving from design stage to implementation stage. So both planned and committed step downs as well as additional value generations beyond that.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Howard Rubel from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Howard Rubel from Jefferies.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: You recent -- Dennis, you recently extended the 787-10 with a new customer, and you've done a number of things with the 777 to enhance it as a value proposition. Could you address a little bit on the market dynamics you see because of the capabilities the
componenttext: You recent -- Dennis, you recently extended the 787-10 with a new customer, and you've done a number of things with the 777 to enhance it as a value proposition. Could you address a little bit on the market dynamics you see because of the capabilities these new airplanes offer and how you see -- the environment for both 777 demand and also the 9 and the 10?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: You bet. Yes. Thanks, Howard. Say, yes, just stepping back, and I know there's been a lot of discussion out there about the widebody marketplace and the prospects going forward, so let me paint for you a market outlook there, and then home in on those 2 s
componenttext: You bet. Yes. Thanks, Howard. Say, yes, just stepping back, and I know there's been a lot of discussion out there about the widebody marketplace and the prospects going forward, so let me paint for you a market outlook there, and then home in on those 2 specific airplanes in particular. But if you take a look at the overall market, we continue to see a growing healthy marketplace. As we've said before, a current market outlook for 38,000 new airplanes over the next 20 years in total. We continue to see strong passenger growth independent assessments again of 6% year-over-year growth throughout the time period. Cargo growth has been more moderated and has been a bit slow to recover, as you know. But we are seeing some recovery signs there. If you take a look at overall market characteristics, we continue to see a strong healthy marketplace, both narrowbodies and widebodies. If you take a look at replacement demand, it continue to be strong. We expect about 40% of those aircraft in that market outlook to be driven by replacement demand. As I said, cancellations and referrals remain below historic levels as well. So the market fundamentals remained strong. Now when we get to the 2 projects you mentioned, on 787, as noted, with 800 aircraft in backlog and a continuing strong market demand, and I think, EVA's decision here just in the last couple of weeks to acquire 24 787-10  is just another good sign of the value that, that product is bringing to the marketplace. The 787 searcher value is delivering value to our customers. The value proposition is clearly a competitive advantage, both in terms of operating cost reduction as well as the advantage in revenue and cargo volume and residual value that it brings to the customers. And with the production efficiencies that we're generating, and we remain very bullish on 787. And as Greg talked about our plans to ramp up to 12 a month and to 14 a month before the end of the decade, all supported by strong market demand and the unique value proposition of that airplane. On the 777, we've been very focused on building up 777 Bridge. We talked about we needed to generate about 40 to 60 orders per year on the current 777 to build that bridge. Year-to-date we've got 44 orders and commitments. So we're continuing to fill out that bridge, in essence. The 777 line is sold out through 2016 more than half sold in 2017, and we continue to it with a number of serious campaigns, all bridging to the 777x. And as you pointed out, the 777x is bringing, again, our unique value proposition to the market. Both today's 777 and the 777x have really no pure competitor in bringing unique value to our customers. And 777x having just completed firm configuration, they've got good solid signs on development programs, being executed on plan and we plan to have EIS on airplane 2020 as scheduled. So in all cases, a strong fundamental market, the right differentiated product line of 787s and 777s. And very mindful right now about building a bridge from the 777 to the 777x.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I just may, on the 78 -- initially, you had teething pains introducing it into the market. Could you just a second, and then I'll end here, address sort of the statute of liability? And how you've improved that? And how that's also helped to lower both
componenttext: If I just may, on the 78 -- initially, you had teething pains introducing it into the market. Could you just a second, and then I'll end here, address sort of the statute of liability? And how you've improved that? And how that's also helped to lower both airline costs and your costs?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: You bet. And we continue to see strong progress. You're right. We've had some challenges as we introduced that airplane into our customer fleets. And we've been very focused on reliability improvement both in the field and in the production line. We've se
componenttext: You bet. And we continue to see strong progress. You're right. We've had some challenges as we introduced that airplane into our customer fleets. And we've been very focused on reliability improvement both in the field and in the production line. We've seen steadily improving dispatch reliability across our customer sets. We're pleased with the progress there. That said, more work to do go. So we're not done, and we're going to continue to describe dispatch reliability there for our customers until we achieved the objectives that we have. So more work to go. I will say that reliability improvements that we've delivered to date in the field and it back driven  into the production line, really taking hold. the sign of that would be roughly 50 Dash 9s that we delivered as they're hitting the fleets, they're coming in and a much higher dispatch reliability then their original Dash 8s. So just further proof that investment were making our delivering value for our customers. And we want to stay very focused to getting to the finish line there.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe one for you. I know timing around events is something that's generally hard to predict. You put out there kind of a placeholder of $3 billion for 2015.  And year-to-date, that hasn't really contributed much. And if you look at the fourth quart
componenttext: Greg, maybe one for you. I know timing around events is something that's generally hard to predict. You put out there kind of a placeholder of $3 billion for 2015.  And year-to-date, that hasn't really contributed much. And if you look at the fourth quarter, obviously, if that came through, it's hard for me to not think that you'd be running $1 billion plus ahead of your revised guidance. So can you help give either the offset more or less just conservatism around not knowing when  that $3 billion is going to tick?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no. I mean, you said it, Miles. They, certainly, they do move around. I'd still expect it to be a positive contributor to 2015. But timing does factor in. So we should have more in the fourth quarter, but I think stepping back from that, you can se
componenttext: Yes -- no. I mean, you said it, Miles. They, certainly, they do move around. I'd still expect it to be a positive contributor to 2015. But timing does factor in. So we should have more in the fourth quarter, but I think stepping back from that, you can see, it's about the strength of the cash engine here and not the reliance on the advances. Obviously, advances are important. But if you look at into the core of the company, you're seeing strong cash flow generation and that's the big focus area for us. And as you said, advances, they're going to move around quarter-to-quarter. And we'll have a few more year in the fourth quarter than we have in the third quarter so...

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And even with the tick up in the revised cash guidance for this year, the outlook is still for growth into '16 from the new level?
componenttext: And even with the tick up in the revised cash guidance for this year, the outlook is still for growth into '16 from the new level?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you step back, and you look at kind of the long-term profile of the company, we still see the same opportunity to have strong cash flow growth going forward. It really plays in to certainly the production rates increases that we've talked
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you step back, and you look at kind of the long-term profile of the company, we still see the same opportunity to have strong cash flow growth going forward. It really plays in to certainly the production rates increases that we've talked about on the 37, the 67 and as well on the 87, over the long term. And obviously, 787 improving through that period. So over the long term, we're confident on the long-term cash flow growth, I'll say, story that we have in place. And I think it's a unique one, when I compare us to other industrials.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll go to Sam Pearlstein with Wells Fargo.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dennis, you talked about in the past being able to get mid-teens margin within the BPA business. And I guess I'm wondering, how comfortable are you still with that and how do things like the 777 transition and volume and actually lower commodity prices, w
componenttext: Dennis, you talked about in the past being able to get mid-teens margin within the BPA business. And I guess I'm wondering, how comfortable are you still with that and how do things like the 777 transition and volume and actually lower commodity prices, which should be lower escalation? How did that play into it? What does it take to get those kinds of and BCA?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sam, yes, we remained focused on that aspirational target. As we talked about before, we see margin growth in BCA as an important priority for us. You're seeing it in the data and the results that we're producing. The productivity actions that Greg d
componenttext: Yes. Sam, yes, we remained focused on that aspirational target. As we talked about before, we see margin growth in BCA as an important priority for us. You're seeing it in the data and the results that we're producing. The productivity actions that Greg described earlier are all part of doing that, part of it is productivity, efficiency inside our own factories, another key portion of that is within our supply chain through our Partnering for Success effort. But if we take a longer term view of what our company can and should be, getting to that mid-teens margin range is an expectation and aspiration that we set for ourselves. And I think that's a smart and aggressive target for the long-term. We're just going to stay very focused on it. As Greg had said, with the backlog that we have and the product line that we have, our opportunity to the generate long-term cash growth and long term margin accretion is very strong. And we are taking the right productivity actions both internally and externally to do that. And that will result in increased return to our shareholders, and it will allow us to fund and invest in our future innovation and talent. So we are very focused on doing that and remain steadfast on that longer-term target.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That regarding your question around 777, as we think about that transition. Obviously, a key topic for us here is as the 777x will begin coming into the production system in the 2018 timeframe, leading to EIS in 2020. As I mentioned earlier, we're buildin
componenttext: That regarding your question around 777, as we think about that transition. Obviously, a key topic for us here is as the 777x will begin coming into the production system in the 2018 timeframe, leading to EIS in 2020. As I mentioned earlier, we're building the 777 bridge with today's current product line leveraging the fact that, that airplane does provide a unique value proposition in the marketplace. We're thinking carefully through exactly how we do that transition and the timing of it. As we talked about before, it's important that we do that efficiently. We're trying to pull ahead some of the technology investment in the line like automation and in the fuselage line to derisk that transition. And as I mentioned earlier, we've already implemented that automation here in the 777 line on the fuselage operate build and that's going well. So that's another way to derisk that transition and ensure profitability through it. There's been a lot of conversations out there about exactly what the shape of that transition might be. And we're factoring in market demand, as I said, some uncertainty around cargo recovery. Frankly, some uncertainty around XM bank reauthorization. Those are factors that could cause some customers to delay decisions around widebodies. So we're being mindful of that. We're going to make sure where going to maintain a highly profitable line through the transition. All of those factors are going into our planning right now. Frankly, with that, we don't see any scenarios where we've come down below a 7 a month production rate during the transition. Import again to remind ourselves that 2016 is essentially sold out. 2017 is more than half sold out. So this transition that we're talking about is a 2017 and beyond transition. And through all of that, we're going to drive this in a way that maximizes profitability of the line through the transition, allows us to continue to invest in the future. And my broader comments about continued cash growth and margin accretion over the long-term all account for that 777 transition. So that's all factored into our bigger game plan.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Greg, I don't know if you can mention anything about commodity cost? And how that affects the escalation and your assumptions in the program accounting? Did it have any effect this quarter?
componenttext: And Greg, I don't know if you can mention anything about commodity cost? And how that affects the escalation and your assumptions in the program accounting? Did it have any effect this quarter?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it didn't, it didn't, Sam. It didn't have much impact at all.
componenttext: No, it didn't, it didn't, Sam. It didn't have much impact at all.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kyle with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kyle with Cowen and Company.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So could you comment whether there is any adjustment to commercial blocks or accrual rate? And kind of relatedly, Dennis, you talked about moderated kind of quarter claim, are you still looking for book-to-bill to get to 1.0 for the year? Because it looks
componenttext: So could you comment whether there is any adjustment to commercial blocks or accrual rate? And kind of relatedly, Dennis, you talked about moderated kind of quarter claim, are you still looking for book-to-bill to get to 1.0 for the year? Because it looks like you're going to have to move pretty quickly to get there. And if so, how does the Chinese border play into that? And what are the implications of kind of getting there or not getting there in terms of potential profitability looking forward?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me take the second part, and then I'll put it to Greg for your first question. So regarding book-to-bill for the year. Again, we continue to see book-to-bill of approximately 1 for the end of the year. As I mentioned, some hesitancy right now in
componenttext: Okay. Let me take the second part, and then I'll put it to Greg for your first question. So regarding book-to-bill for the year. Again, we continue to see book-to-bill of approximately 1 for the end of the year. As I mentioned, some hesitancy right now in the widebody marketplace around cargo recovery and uncertainty with the XM bank. That's causing some customers to pause a bit on decision making, so it's more of a timing issue rather than a volume issue. So we still anticipate book-to-bill to be roughly 1 by the end of the year. Some decisions could slide into the earlier part of the new year. Frankly, with about 5,700 aircraft in backlog, annual book-to-bill ratios are not that important to us. We're continuing to generate orders pipeline. But timing quarter-to-quarter, it happens to shift a bit with that kind of backlog that we have, we remain very confident in the long-term plan. As you mentioned, the recent announcement by our customers in China was very positive for us. We were honored to host President Shea [ph] at our factory in Everett a couple of weeks ago. Amongst the number of agreements that's included in the announcement of around 300 aircraft, 250 narrowbodies and 50 widebodies. Some of those are airplanes that were already in backlog but unidentified. Others are incremental new commitments. And we'll be working through the specific deals on those airplanes with our customers over the next many months, and we'll announce those as they come to fruition. But that will generally create upside to our book-to-bill posture for the end of the year. Greg, do you want to take the first question.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, can I -- on block extensions, we extended the 737 by 200 aircraft, so 1 block extension there. And then with the increased demand and outlook on the 767, we increased that as well by 34 units. As far as changing in booking rates by program, no signif
componenttext: Yes, can I -- on block extensions, we extended the 737 by 200 aircraft, so 1 block extension there. And then with the increased demand and outlook on the 767, we increased that as well by 34 units. As far as changing in booking rates by program, no significant changes, I'd say, across the board.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. One quick clarification question and then an immediate one. Dennis, you mentioned the rate of 7 a month on the 777. Would you be firing blanks in that environment? That's the clarification question, and an immediate question and one for Greg on CapEx
componenttext: Yes. One quick clarification question and then an immediate one. Dennis, you mentioned the rate of 7 a month on the 777. Would you be firing blanks in that environment? That's the clarification question, and an immediate question and one for Greg on CapEx out into the future. Can you talk about the puts and takes that you're likely to see over the next couple of years on CapEx?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, on the first question there, yes, that will be factored into the overall transition plans. As you're well aware, that's a very common practice for us as we transition model mixes in our high-volume lines as we go from 777 to 777X, where we could pu
componenttext: Jason, on the first question there, yes, that will be factored into the overall transition plans. As you're well aware, that's a very common practice for us as we transition model mixes in our high-volume lines as we go from 777 to 777X, where we could pull technology and implementation ahead as we're doing with automation we will. That will make the transition even smoother. In some cases, we will fire selected blanks down the production line. Then again that will help us smooth out implementation and ensure lean implementation. Note that we'll also add some 777 flight test -- excuse me 777 X flight test aircraft that will flow through the production system in that same timeframe. So all of that will be factored into the production profile in the transition plan. But again as I said, we've looked through all the options and variables what's from a market demand standpoint from a production efficiency standpoint. We don't see any scenarios that would take us below a 7 a month production rate. And we're very confident that we can achieve that implementation, remain very profitable in that line while we do it and successfully bring the 777X into the marketplace.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jason, on CapEx, we'll expect to go up slightly next year from our levels this year, and again, that's supporting the growth in the production rates we talked about in further investments in the defense business as well as some of the productivity ini
componenttext: And Jason, on CapEx, we'll expect to go up slightly next year from our levels this year, and again, that's supporting the growth in the production rates we talked about in further investments in the defense business as well as some of the productivity initiatives. So further implementation of the automation activity on the 37 and the 87 will also be put into play there. And again, supporting 777X as well as the planned production rates. And then I would say, past '16 then we start to come down and moderate from there as really through the again link to our growth and link through our investment profile.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll go to Ron Epstein with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick question for you -- for Greg. When you're balancing return to shareholders versus long-term value. And kind of in the context to this, and I'm thinking about the share buybacks, year-to-date you guys bought back -- if I did the math right, 41.5 mi
componenttext: A quick question for you -- for Greg. When you're balancing return to shareholders versus long-term value. And kind of in the context to this, and I'm thinking about the share buybacks, year-to-date you guys bought back -- if I did the math right, 41.5 million shares for about $6 billion, right?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That implies an average cost of maybe $144 to $145 per share. That's  within about 10% of the historical highs of the stock. I mean, how do you think about that?
componenttext: That implies an average cost of maybe $144 to $145 per share. That's  within about 10% of the historical highs of the stock. I mean, how do you think about that?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think those stock is still undervalued. And again, I think it goes to the marketplace that Dennis talked about. It goes to the strength of the backlog, which then links to the production rates that we've announced that are again delivering on tha
componenttext: Well, we think those stock is still undervalued. And again, I think it goes to the marketplace that Dennis talked about. It goes to the strength of the backlog, which then links to the production rates that we've announced that are again delivering on that backlog. So it's that profile along with the productivity expectations year-over-year. So we see, obviously, see a lot of value still left in that stock. That's why we bought back $20 billion in the last 3 years and remained committed to that. At the same time, we remained committed to the dividend to ensure that we're competitive from a dividend perspective as well as investing in the business. And that's been first and foremost for us, investing in things like 777X, like the MAX, like 787-9 and 10. And these rate increases, along with, again, efficiencies, automation that we're putting in on 777, we're putting on 37 and then additional investments for making down in Charleston to support, again, productivity and rate increases. So that's the kind of profile we see that gives us the confidence to continue to buy back these shares but have a balanced deployment plan to meet all of our objectives.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I may just a follow-on, given that everybody asked about 5 questions. How do you guys think about the middle of the market airplane? That's something we've been thinking about a lot. And there's been a lot of chatter about that in the indust
componenttext: Great. And if I may just a follow-on, given that everybody asked about 5 questions. How do you guys think about the middle of the market airplane? That's something we've been thinking about a lot. And there's been a lot of chatter about that in the industry. I mean, how do you think about the potential market opportunity and what investment would be required?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We still see that as a niche market but an important one. And we're having conversations with our customers. We see today that, that market space is largely served by our 737 MAX, 8 and 9 family and on the upper end, by the 787. And we think that in
componenttext: Yes. We still see that as a niche market but an important one. And we're having conversations with our customers. We see today that, that market space is largely served by our 737 MAX, 8 and 9 family and on the upper end, by the 787. And we think that in large part serves  that market space. It's important that a lot of our customers their buying behavior and their needs are related to families of aircraft, and we still see in that narrowbody marketplace the MAX 8 is being at the heart of the market, augmented with the MAX 9 to serve some of those needs that are in the more in the middle of the market segment. So for the near-term, we see our current product line as being the right answer for that segment. That segment continue to have conversations with our customers. And if we need to respond with a new airplane in that market place, that would be something that would be more towards the end of the next decade. It's not something that would dramatically affect our R&D profiles over the next 4 to 5 years. We think those profiles are very solid with our current development programs. But it is something we're keeping an eye on, continuing to talk with our customers to understand their needs. And if the market demands a response, we'll be ready.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Seth Seifman with J.P. Morgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Seth Seifman with J.P. Morgan.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you can get into the 787 a little bit more and what you're expecting in Q4, not to nitpick too much, but you talked about how the decline in deferred growth in Q4, but now we're starting from a lower level, so just maybe a little bit more color on how
componenttext: If you can get into the 787 a little bit more and what you're expecting in Q4, not to nitpick too much, but you talked about how the decline in deferred growth in Q4, but now we're starting from a lower level, so just maybe a little bit more color on how to think about that. And if you could explain a little bit about the dynamics as we head into 2016 and kind of why it plateaus for a little while before coming down at 12 months.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure -- no. We'll see it inflated the third and fourth quarter, it's a similar to the rate of decline you've seen in this quarter, in Q3, certainly he'd helped by strong performance. But we did have some timing of expenditures as well. So we had a li
componenttext: Yes, sure -- no. We'll see it inflated the third and fourth quarter, it's a similar to the rate of decline you've seen in this quarter, in Q3, certainly he'd helped by strong performance. But we did have some timing of expenditures as well. So we had a little bit of, I'll say, favorable hiccup in the third quarter, but again, I think if you step back and look at the overall propeller deferred to date, it's better than what we originally projected. And then as you move into '16, Seth, as I said, you'll start to see that trend, once you hit the 12-month. So the growth will moderate, obviously, into the fourth order, and then through into '16, so you hit that great and the so that will be what you would expect to turn. And that turn down again is driven by the rate as well as the step down in the supply chain the contracted step down pricing and the continued productivity. But also that mix, I mean, ensuring that, that we've got that Dash 9 continues to come into the production system that it has. So those are kind of, I'd say, the key indicators or key levers as we move into '16.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Carter Copeland with Barclays.

componenttext: Greg, I wondered if we could go back to the margins for a second, just another view. You extended a block 200 units on the 37, but the no material margin increase their wonder why that was, I assume that all Maxis, and then on the 777, Dennis, your comment about trying to maintain that margin rate to the extent possible, you obviously have some pretty significant extra costs there when you transition over the surge line from the 87 to the 777. Did that cost, is in the 777X block or is called or hold during the. How should we think about how you manage that 2 different programs going now to seem like, because there's always the significant costs there. So any color would be much appreciated.

componenttext: Let me, if all right, I'll answer the question. The slight pick up, quarter, but again, 200 units on a large block. So there's a lot of moving pieces in there. There some investment in there for additional rate increases and productivity. So when you net that all outcome again, not a significant change on overall booking rates for the quarter.

componenttext: And then your second question, the 777, as you know, the R&D investment, the cap ex investment that were making to bring 777X online come are hard of the profile that we shared with you in terms for total R&D in cap ex investment where we can bulldoze forward and implement on the 777 line to reduce risk like the piece lunch upright build were doing that. headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Levenson with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Levenson with Stifel.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you please expand your comments on the upward pressure in single oil rates? And if you could let us know the supply-chain particularly on engines?
componenttext: Can you please expand your comments on the upward pressure in single oil rates? And if you could let us know the supply-chain particularly on engines?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We take a look at the market there, Steve, it continues to show signs of strength and growth. What we're seeing from customers in terms of market demand, especially for 737 MAX, continues to be positive sign press. We told to you that we're at 40 to
componenttext: Yes. We take a look at the market there, Steve, it continues to show signs of strength and growth. What we're seeing from customers in terms of market demand, especially for 737 MAX, continues to be positive sign press. We told to you that we're at 40 to a month right now, we're ramping to 47 a month and 52 a month by 2018. Those are committed pleasant we have in place. We continue to do studies on possibilities of ramping up beyond that. As I said earlier, we're going to maintain very strict financial discipline as we do those studies, being very mindful about it. We are still in a slightly overbooked position in terms of our order profile for the 737. And all of that just creates general upward pressure to production rates. We're going to be very fiscally responsible us we consider those options. Again, our committed plan and takes this out through 2018. So we have time to consider these alternatives beyond that.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The other thing that I'd like to factor in is the 737 MAX development, the fact that we've achieved a power on in the first airplane the final assembly is on or ahead of schedule, also gives us confidence in terms of the airplane coming together and being
componenttext: The other thing that I'd like to factor in is the 737 MAX development, the fact that we've achieved a power on in the first airplane the final assembly is on or ahead of schedule, also gives us confidence in terms of the airplane coming together and being ready for EIS with our customers. So both the development program progress as well as the market demand signals show us that narrowbodies are very robust market for us, both short and here and long-term.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Again, any pushback from suppliers?
componenttext: Again, any pushback from suppliers?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we continue to talk to our supply chain, and certainly, is ramping up to the degree that we're ramping up, and something that we had to pay attention to our supply chain is there's nowhere that they see pressure point that we need to work together.
componenttext: Well, we continue to talk to our supply chain, and certainly, is ramping up to the degree that we're ramping up, and something that we had to pay attention to our supply chain is there's nowhere that they see pressure point that we need to work together. Nothing that I would say is out of the ordinary, these are normal ramp up pressures. And we know how to do the scrap pressures, we've done a number over the last few years. We've got a few important ones during the next 5 years. But were working across integrated supply chains and making sure that the have the capacity and that capability to deliver and our needs is an important part of the equation. That's one of the things that we factor into our committed plans. We remain very confident that our supply chain can meet our ramp up to 52 a month on the MAX. If we were to go beyond that, factoring in supply chain capability is a key component of that decision. Again, we have plenty of time to make that decision with the committed plans that we already have in place.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Operator, we have what time for one more question.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: And that will be from Rob Spingarn with Crdit Suisse.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Dennis, I wanted to ask you on the buyback. But before I get to that, just a quick question for Greg. Given that, can we expect that your buyback at the current levels should continue unabated going forward, roughly those levels?

componenttext: And to you go-forward question, Rob. Again, as we look at the priorities to cash deployments over the next several years, cat priorities remains organic investment. And this is delivering an hour and delivery programs like the 777X, the MAX, the 787-that, we're confident and that and as we've said before, with appeasing up those programs, our R&D profile year-to-year, we expect to remain consistent and should so that should give you confidence that our R&D foundation is not going to vary significantly year-to-year, that will be up additional investment, that's not to the decline over the next 5 years. Second priority, as we said, is returning strong value to our shareholders, both in the form of dividends and share repurchase. We expect that to continue to be a strong component of our overall cash deployment over the next many years. And then thirdly, any targeted actions we might take in the M&A arena, acquisition arena, that would be a third priority in that list. We're going to remain very focused on those priorities. And the fact that we expect long-term cash growth will allow us to fuel those future investments and things like share repurchase.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me fill the first lender and Greg I'll ask you to touch on the second one. Yes, Julie, regarding 777, assays that are doing or scenario planning right now that includes market demand and feedback you're hearing from our customers. And includes the val
componenttext: Let me fill the first lender and Greg I'll ask you to touch on the second one. Yes, Julie, regarding 777, assays that are doing or scenario planning right now that includes market demand and feedback you're hearing from our customers. And includes the value proposition of the 777 and the 777X and I want to stress again that, that airplane is providing an absolutely unique value proposition in the marketplace. It's depreciated. And our customers see it. And then also doing an efficient and profitable transition from 777 to 777X. So those are all things at where factoring into our plan. We haven't finalized that plan yet. We're working through. For a variety of options that but as we look through all of those options, we don't see any scenarios that will take us below a 7 a month production rate. So we wanted to make sure that, that was clear and there's been speculation about what option reach we might look at. We see that as a forward planning, given all the snares were looking at. Specific timing, implementation, is yet to be finalized. Working our way through those details there will be decisions will have to make in the first part of next year. But I'll stress again that we are sold out essentially through 2016, more than half sold out through 2017. So what we're talking about here's a transition that's out 2017 and beyond. And we would get into the meat of that in the 2018 timeframe. So more details to be worked through. But remain confident that considering all the factors I've talked about that be will be able to profitable growth through that transition and bring the 777X to the marketplace.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julie, on 747, as you know, this has been a challenging marketplace recently. And we've announced taking the rate down from 1.3 to 1 a month early in '16. So we continue to monitor that marketplace. It is challenging right now, it's driven by the mar
componenttext: Yes, Julie, on 747, as you know, this has been a challenging marketplace recently. And we've announced taking the rate down from 1.3 to 1 a month early in '16. So we continue to monitor that marketplace. It is challenging right now, it's driven by the market. It's a great airplane, it's an airplane at pics in the class within itself, whether it's an I  or a freighter. So it's really market dynamics. We've got a pipeline of customers were looking at. But again, having said that, it's a challenging market place for the airplane. So we continue to watch it. And at the same time, focus on productivity within the factories and the supply chain. And we'll likely take another look at that early next year and see where we are in orders in backlog and move forward from there. But right now, the plan is to hold it 1 a month.

Given the amount of portfolio shaping that's going on against the private side, Dennis, how comfortable are you with  a shape of the DDS right now, particularly in military aircraft and space, you are comfortable with that regardless of what happens with some big upcoming launch.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, we are. As I said before, we have a strong robust, healthy defense business. Now it's a tough market place, and we've acknowledged that. We're dealing with the realities of sequestration in the U.S. Defense market. Somewhat offset by what we've
componenttext: Yes, Doug, we are. As I said before, we have a strong robust, healthy defense business. Now it's a tough market place, and we've acknowledged that. We're dealing with the realities of sequestration in the U.S. Defense market. Somewhat offset by what we've seen as international Defense growth, especially the Middle East and Asia-Pacific regions. But our defense business, overall, is a healthy portfolio. We like the program structures we have. We're growing internationally. And we're investing for the long run. That marketplace is some what muted. So expect that business to be relatively flat to slight growth top line in parallel with that, we're continuing to drive bottom line performance. And you saw in the results there with at 12.2% margin quarter and our defense business. So that's our robust, important part of our portfolio. We have differentiated product lines some things like commercial derivatives and TA in the tanker that for me percent us with opportunities for long-term growth and leverage them the Boeing value that,  if you will, across commercial and defense sectors, are continuing to invest in future product lines around human space expiration, satellites, or investing in unmanned systems and ISR capabilities. And importantly, we are investing for some critical franchise programs for the future. You alluded to that, but that programs like Long Range Strike, the new T-X trainer, are important. And one of the reasons we won we continue to drive productivity so we can invest in those future product lines. And so we don't see a need to significantly change the structure of our defense business. I mean We're going to stay very focused on executing on the business, investing organically and where we can make targeted acquisitions to round out our portfolio, we'll continue to do that.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with the Seattle Times.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dominic Gates with the Seattle Times.

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have -- I just want to clarify couple of things about the 777 rate question. The EIS for 777X is 2020. But presumably, that's going to ramp up over several years. So the first question about the bridge is, like, how far beyond 2020 are you still having
componenttext: I have -- I just want to clarify couple of things about the 777 rate question. The EIS for 777X is 2020. But presumably, that's going to ramp up over several years. So the first question about the bridge is, like, how far beyond 2020 are you still having to fill a bridge for the current 777 model? And then secondly, you gave us some reassurance that the floor for the production rate in the bridge is 7 a month, but you also mentioned firing blanks. And can you give us some idea, like how many blanks are we talking about? If it was 1 a month, that's very different from 1 or 2 a year. So give us some guidance there?

headline: The Boeing Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dominic, to the first part of your question, if you look at the direction of the bridge, you're right, 777X, and EIS is in 2020. As we said, the bridge were trying to build with the current 777 is roughly a five-year bridge. So takes us to that same
componenttext: Yes, Dominic, to the first part of your question, if you look at the direction of the bridge, you're right, 777X, and EIS is in 2020. As we said, the bridge were trying to build with the current 777 is roughly a five-year bridge. So takes us to that same timeframe. The depth of that bridge is most significant in the 2018, 2019 timeframe. So we're very focused on filling that out. And we need about 40 to 60 aircraft per year over that 5 years to fill that bridge. So that effort continues to press ahead. Now when you think about the transition production rate, the fact that we'll fire some selective blanks through the line, that is not a high volume decision to your point. This is something that we'll do selectively as we bring Lean implementation online in the new production rig. We haven't finalized exactly how many that will be. But those will be -- those are incremental, not a sustained activity. And then also, mindful, we will have some 777X flight test aircraft, typical numbers up flight test aircraft, principally in a 2018, 2019 timeframe, that will be within that production line as well. So both of those are being factored into the profile.
